title: Gender Stereotype Threat and Memory Performance in a Heading-Recall Task
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This project investigates whether gender stereotype threat influences memory performance in a heading-recall task. Data were collected from 35 participants across 1,400+ trials, cleaned in Excel, and analyzed in Jamovi using ANOVA. While results were not statistically significant, suggestive patterns indicated that stereotype threat may influence recall. Completed as a class project, the findings were presented as a poster at the CMU Department of Psychology undergraduate research session.

title: Learning Relational Rules: Effects of Training Structure and Task Difficulty
text:
Advisors: Julia Conti (graduate mentor) and Paulo Carvalho (PI)
This project investigates how people learn relational rules, focusing on the effects of rule complexity and training structure. Using experimental tasks and multilevel modeling, we tested whether mastery varies with task difficulty, whether prior exposure improves accuracy, and whether interleaved pre-training enhances performance. Results showed that mastery gaps emerged only on harder tasks, prior exposure had modest benefits, and interleaved training had no significant effect, highlighting the role of individual differences in rule learning.

title: County-Level Determinants of Obesity: Lifestyle and Food Environment Analysis
text:
Collaborators: Anvith Thumma and Jordan Faustin
This project investigates county-level determinants of adult obesity in the U.S. using the 2025 County Health Rankings & Roadmaps dataset. Exploratory analyses, including scatter plots and correlation matrices, were conducted, and a Huber regression model was fitted to identify predictors of regional variation in obesity rates. Findings revealed strong associations between obesity and both physical inactivity and food access, though results are correlational rather than causal. The results were presented as a poster, presentation, and report during a Q&A session with UnitedHealth Group professionals and statistics faculty.

title: Predicting Flight Delays at Pittsburgh International Airport
text:
Collaborator: Emily Jiang
Instructor: Spencer Koerner
This project investigates the prediction of flight delays at Pittsburgh International Airport using historical flight data from 2022–2023. A random forest classifier was trained to forecast 2024 delays, achieving 78% prediction accuracy. Completed as a class project, the findings were submitted as a written report and demonstrate the practical application of machine learning techniques to transportation data.

title: Bookshelf
text:
Favorite Quotes

Favorite Books




































Favorite Comics
I’ve read a ton of X-Men over the years. Beyond the powers and fight scenes, what sticks with me is how it reflects real-world struggles faced by marginalized communities. I’ve always loved how Magneto and Professor X parallel Malcolm X and Martin Luther King Jr. That contrast in ideology makes the story hit harder. I love the series so much that I used to have a whole screenshot stash of the funniest X-Men moments, but it got lost somewhere along the way. So here’s to starting fresh and rebuilding the archive.

title: Impact of Incentives on Visual Search Performance
text:
Collaborators: Cami Streuly, Shirley Du, and Cole Kaforey
Instructor: Abigail Noyce
This project investigates whether performance incentives improve efficiency in visual search tasks. Participants completed multiple search trials in Gorilla, and data were cleaned and analyzed in Jamovi using ANOVA. Results suggested modest effects of incentives, though findings were not statistically significant, likely due to the limited sample size. Completed as a class project, the findings were submitted as a written paper.

title: Gender Stereotype Threat Interventions and Academic Performance
text:
Collaborators: Amor Ai, Sisley Yang, Frank Janicke, Eesha Nagpal, and Camille Chandler
Instructor: Phoebe Lam
This project investigates the impact of gender stereotype threat on academic performance through a meta-analysis. Out of 117 studies screened, 13 peer-reviewed articles met inclusion criteria, and effect sizes were synthesized using R. Results showed that both affirmative and non-affirmative interventions improved performance compared to no intervention, though subgroup analyses were limited by small sample sizes. Completed as a class project, the findings were written up in a formal IMRaD-style research paper and highlight the importance of intervention strategies in mitigating stereotype threat in educational settings.

title: Exploring Mental Health Among COVID-19 Graduates
text:
Instructor: Roberto Vargas
This project investigates mental health outcomes for undergraduates graduating during the COVID-19 pandemic’s peak (2020) versus its decline (2021). Survey data from over 100 respondents were analyzed using principal component analysis, logistic regression, and bootstrap sampling in R. Results suggested that students graduating during the pandemic’s decline reported greater psychological distress than those graduating at its peak. Completed as a class project, the findings were written up as a research report and provide evidence of the long-term psychological impacts of disrupted educational transitions.

title: Patterns in Medical Incident Records: Statistical Insights for Care Improvement
text:
Collaborators: Emily Zhu, Sophia Mou, Alva He, Derek Gao, and Edward Brownhill
This project investigates patterns in medical incident records at Mainstay Life Services, a nonprofit supporting individuals with intellectual disabilities and autism. We analyzed incident types, needs levels, and time-to-report using Fisher’s exact tests, time-series modeling, survival analysis, and Kruskal–Wallis tests. My primary contribution focused on medication error incidents, culminating in a detailed statistical report and a team presentation. The findings highlight trends in incident reporting and provide actionable insights for improving care quality.

title: Helen Peng
text:
I’m a senior at Carnegie Mellon University, majoring in Statistics with a concentration in Psychology. I’m interested in using data to address real-world challenges, especially in public health and education. Currently, I’m part of the OAK Lab , where I investigate relational rule learning, how people learn and discover complex rules.
Outside of academics, I spend my free time exploring stories through books, TV shows, and media that reveal how people think, connect, and navigate the world. These stories are my favorite way to recharge and reflect, and you can find a few of them under the bookshelf tab.
